html:
• anchor

    Aerial view of West Palm Street, Altadena after the Eaton Fire. Image courtesy Google Maps

    Altadena’s value isn’t just in its square footage; it’s one of the few remaining communities of generational working-class homeowners in Los Angeles County. If this pace of corporate acquisition continues, some houses might get rebuilt—but who will live in them, and under what terms? — Dwell

    An investigation by Dwell has found that of the 150 damaged properties that have been sold in Altadena since devastating wildfires earlier this year, at least 50% have been purchased by corporate entities. The outlet further found that 42% of those sales were held by just six companies, each of which has purchased four or more homes. 

    Among the top buyers is Black Lion Properties, operated by Edwin Castro. An architecture graduate of Woodbury University, Castro made news for winning the record-breaking $2 billion Powerball lottery in 2022. Black Lion has "quietly acquired" 15 properties in Altadena for almost $9 million, Dwell reports. 

    Speaking to the outlet, architect and Altadena Collective co-founder Tim Volrdtriede said he was "very concerned—but also in that same way we’re feeling about the rest of the world: concerned, but don’t know how to fix it." Vordtriede further expressed concern that speculative buying could reshape the architectural character of the areas before residents could return, adding: "Survivors are not guinea pigs."
